questions.text: A teenage patient presented with a history of dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain. On ultrasonography, a transverse vaginal septum was seen. Which of the following is she likely to have? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endometriosis

 

Endometriosis:

 

  • A transverse vaginal septum is a type of Mullerian anomaly, which can be low, mid, or high and can be complete or incomplete.
  • It can present as primary amenorrhea with cyclical abdominal pain if complete.
  • The obstruction to blood flow caused by a transverse vaginal septum can lead to the accumulation of blood in the vagina (hematocolpos) and uterus (hematometra), which can subsequently cause retrograde menstruation and result in endometriosis.
  • The chronic pelvic pain and dysmenorrhea in this patient are consistent with endometriosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tubo-ovarian abscess: Tubo-ovarian abscess is typically associated with pelvic inflammatory disease and presents with fever, lower abdominal pain, and a tender adnexal mass. It is not directly related to Mullerian anomalies like a transverse vaginal septum.

 

Option C. Dermoid cyst: Dermoid cysts (mature cystic teratomas) are benign ovarian tumors that typically do not cause dysmenorrhea or chronic pelvic pain related to menstrual obstruction. They are not associated with Mullerian anomalies.

 

Option D. Theca lutein cyst: Theca lutein cysts are often associated with high levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) and are seen in conditions like molar pregnancy and multiple gestations. They do not cause symptoms related to menstrual obstruction and are not associated with Mullerian anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transverse vaginal septum, a Mullerian anomaly, can cause obstruction to menstrual flow leading to hematocolpos, hematometra, and endometriosis, presenting with dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain.

 

Ref: Page no 34, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text: After a severe penetrating head trauma, what is the risk of subsequent epilepsy? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 45%

 

Explanation:

 

According to Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, the risk of developing subsequent epilepsy after severe penetrating head trauma is approximately 45%. This statistic highlights the significant risk associated with severe brain injuries, particularly those involving penetration, which can lead to long-term neurological complications such as epilepsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The risk of developing epilepsy after severe penetrating head trauma is approximately 45%.

questions.text: Identify the maneuver being performed in the given image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Head tilt, chin lift

 

The maneuver performed in the given image is that of a head-tilt chin-lift. It is an important technique in emergency airway management to open up the airway.

 

  • Tilt the patient’s head back by pushing down on the forehead.
  • Place the tips of your index and middle fingers under the chin and pull up on the mandible (not on the soft tissues). This lifts the tongue away from the posterior pharynx and improves airway patency.

 

There is no absolute contraindication to it but Suspected cervical injury is a relative contraindication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Jaw thrust: Lift the mandible upward with your fingers, at least until the lower incisors are higher than the upper incisors. This maneuver lifts the tongue along with the mandible, thus relieving upper airway obstruction.

 

 

Option D. Manual inline stabilization: is a neck immobilisation technique in a natural position achieved by using the fingers and palms of both hands to stabilize the patient's occiput and mastoid processes to gently counteract the forces of airway intervention

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The head-tilt chin-lift maneuver is a key technique for opening the airway in emergency situations, especially when cervical spine injury is not suspected.

questions.text: A 52-year-old lady develops sudden onset facial deviation with slurring of speech and inability to raise right arm. The symptoms spontaneously begin to reduce and has significant improvement over the next 48 hours. She has a mid-diastolic murmur on auscultation and irregular heart rhythm. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cardio-embolic stroke

 

Explanation

 

The patient presents with sudden onset neurological deficits (facial deviation, slurred speech, and right arm weakness), which improved significantly over 48 hours. The presence of a mid-diastolic murmur suggests mitral stenosis, and the irregular heart rhythm indicates atrial fibrillation. These are strong risk factors for cardio-embolic stroke. Although the improvement suggests a transient ischemic attack (TIA), the symptoms lasted more than 24 hours, which aligns with the definition of a stroke rather than a TIA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TIA: By definition, a TIA's symptoms resolve within 24 hours. Since the symptoms persisted for more than 24 hours, this is not a TIA.

 

Option B. Thrombo-embolic stroke: While possible, the presence of mitral stenosis and atrial fibrillation makes cardio-embolic stroke more likely.

 

Option D. Paradoxical embolism: This occurs when a thrombus from the venous system passes through a right-to-left cardiac shunt (e.g., patent foramen ovale) into the arterial system. There is no mention of such a shunt or a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardio-embolic stroke should be suspected in patients with sudden onset neurological deficits and risk factors such as mitral stenosis and atrial fibrillation. Symptoms persisting for more than 24 hours distinguish stroke from TIA.

questions.text: A woman presenting with symptoms of urinary tract infection was prescribed a drug that causes tendon rupture and arthropathy. What is the mechanism of action of the drug? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) DNA gyrase inhibition

 

The description of a drug causing tendon rupture and arthropathy, especially in the context of treating a urinary tract infection, points towards a fluoroquinolone antibiotic. Fluoroquinolones, such as ciprofloxacin, work by inhibiting bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, which are essential for bacterial DNA replication and transcription.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ribosomal Inhibition: Antibiotics that inhibit ribosomes, such as macrolides, tetracyclines, and aminoglycosides, affect protein synthesis. These drugs are not typically associated with tendon rupture or arthropathy.

 

Option C. Cell Wall Synthesis Inhibition: Drugs that inhibit cell wall synthesis, like beta-lactams (penicillins, cephalosporins) and vancomycin, are not known to cause tendon rupture or arthropathy as a common side effect.

 

Option D. Inhibition of Folic Acid Synthesis: Antibiotics that inhibit folic acid synthesis, such as sulfonamides and trimethoprim, do not typically cause tendon rupture or arthropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluoroquinolones, which inhibit DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, are associated with serious side effects such as tendon rupture and arthropathy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman came for a routine antenatal check-up in her second trimester. Four years back, she delivered 2 healthy full-term twins. What would her obstetric score be? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) G2P1

 

2 formulas

 

1. G __ P __ L __ A ___

 

  • Gravida (G): The number of times a woman has conceived including the present pregnancy irrespective of the gestational age or the outcome.
  • Para (P): The number of times a pregnancy has crossed the period of viability (taken as 28 weeks for all practical purposes) EXCLUDING the present pregnancy.
  • Living (L): The total number of living children the woman has.
  • Abortion (A): The total number of times the pregnancy has resulted in an abortion/ pregnancy has not crossed the period of viability.

 

IMPORTANT: A Twin pregnancy which has crossed the period of viability is considered as Para 1 NOT Para 2. If it results in 2 living children, it will be Live 2.

 

2. P A-B-C-D (A: term; B: preterm; C: abortions; D: Living)

 

  • This is another way to write the formula.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. G2P2: Incorrect because the woman has had only one previous pregnancy that reached viability, not two.

 

Option B. G3P2: Incorrect because this implies she has had three pregnancies and two have reached viability, which is not the case.

 

Option D. G3P1: Incorrect because this implies three pregnancies, but she is currently in her second pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A twin pregnancy that has crossed the period of viability is considered as Para 1, not Para 2. If it results in two living children, it will be Live 2.

 

Ref: Page no 469, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which nerve is most commonly damaged after parotid surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Facial nerve

 

The Facial nerve (Cranial Nerve VII) is the most commonly damaged nerve during parotid gland surgery due to its anatomical course through the gland. Damage to this nerve can result in facial paralysis or weakness, affecting expressions and other functions like eyelid closure and stapedius muscle reflex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The Trigeminal nerve (Cranial Nerve V) is responsible for sensation in the face and motor functions such as biting and chewing. It is less commonly damaged during parotid surgery because of its location and the type of sensory and motor innervation it provides.

 

Option C. The Glossopharyngeal nerve (Cranial Nerve IX) is involved in taste on the posterior one-third of the tongue and swallowing. It is not typically at risk during parotid surgery as it does not traverse the parotid gland like the facial nerve.

 

Option D. The Accessory nerve (Cranial Nerve XI) innervates the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles and is not usually at risk during parotid surgery because it does not run through the parotid gland.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Facial nerve is the most commonly damaged nerve during parotid surgery due to its anatomical path through the parotid gland, making it vulnerable to injury during surgical procedures involving this gland

questions.text: A patient suffered from severe chest pain and expired. Which of the following is the likely age of infarct from the image of the cardiac biopsy shown here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 day

 

The cardiac biopsy image shows significant neutrophilic infiltration, which is a hallmark of early myocardial infarction.

 

 Neutrophilic infiltration in myocardial tissue occurs in two phases: early (within 24 hours) and late (after 24 hours).

 

In the early phase, neutrophils begin to infiltrate the infarcted tissue within the first 24 hours, but their numbers are relatively low. By the second and third days, neutrophil infiltration becomes more pronounced as the body attempts to clear the dead tissue. However, after 72 hours, neutrophils start to be replaced by macrophages. In this question, the presence of numerous neutrophils indicates that the infarct age is close to 1 day, as significant neutrophil accumulation typically peaks around 24 to 48 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 3-4 days: By this time, neutrophils are starting to be replaced by macrophages, which are responsible for further cleanup and early stages of healing. Therefore, extensive neutrophilic infiltration would not be seen at this stage.

 

Option C. 7-10 days: At this point, granulation tissue is starting to form, and macrophages predominate the area. Neutrophils would not be the primary cells observed, making this answer incorrect.

 

Option D. 2-3 weeks: By 2-3 weeks, granulation tissue is well established, and the repair process is progressing toward fibrosis. Neutrophils would not be present in large numbers at this stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brisk neutrophilic infiltration is a characteristic finding in myocardial tissue within the first 24 hours of infarction. The peak of neutrophil presence occurs around the second and third days, followed by the transition to macrophages.

choices.text: Anti-gas gangrene serum indicated for all cases
Urinary diversion is the next step

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with sudden-onset perineal pain. On examination, foul-smelling discharge, and necrotic tissue as seen in the image is noted. Which of the following is true about the given condition?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection

 

The given scenario and image is most likely to be of Fournier gangrene which is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection.

 

FOURNIER’S GANGRENE

 

  • Synergistic gangrene of scrotum and perineum
  • Limited to skin and fascial planes - type of necrotising fasciitis
  • Never breaches the tunica, testis always spared
  • Risk factors - Low immunity, uncontrolled diabetes

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-gas gangrene serum indicated for all cases: Anti-gas gangrene serum is obsolete now.

 

Option B. Urinary diversion is the next step: Urinary diversion is not the next best step.

 

Option C. Bilateral orchidectomy must be done: Testes are preserved during debridement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fournier gangrene is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection.

questions.text: All of the following structures are derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Linea semilunaris

 

Linea semilunaris is derived from the aponeurosis of the internal oblique muscle.

 

The linea semilunaris is a curved tendinous line located on either side of the rectus abdominis muscle, representing the lateral border where the flat abdominal muscles' aponeuroses come together.

 

It is not derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique alone. Instead, it is formed where the aponeurosis of the external oblique, the internal oblique, and the transversus abdominis meet and fuse before they envelop the rectus abdominis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pectineal Ligament: Also known as Cooper's ligament, the pectineal ligament is a fibrous band that runs parallel and posterior to the inguinal ligament, extending from the pubic tubercle to the pectineal line of the pubis. While it is closely related to structures formed by the aponeurosis of the external oblique, it is not directly derived from it.

 

Option B. Inguinal Ligament: The inguinal ligament is directly derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle. It is the inferior edge of the external oblique aponeurosis, stretching between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic tubercle. This ligament acts as a boundary between the anterior abdominal wall and the thigh, and structures like the spermatic cord in males and the round ligament in females pass beneath it to enter the inguinal canal.

 

Option C. Lacunar Ligament: Also called Gimbernat’s ligament, the lacunar ligament is a crescent-shaped fold of the aponeurosis of the external oblique that attaches to the pectineal line of the pubis. It's positioned medial to the inguinal ligament, and its formation is related to the deepening of the inguinal canal during development. It contributes to the posterior margin of the superficial inguinal ring and represents the lateral border of the femoral canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ligaments derived from external oblique aponeurosis are:

questions.text: A farmer was sleeping in the field, and he felt a sting on his leg. He saw something moving away quickly. He then got drowsy and was taken to the hospital. He developed pain around the site and continued to bleed profusely from the wound site. The wound became red with blisters. Which of the following is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Viper

 

Since, the patient is bleeding profusely from the wound site, the most likely cause is a bite of viper snake, a vasculotoxic snake.

 

  • Cobra is a neurotoxic snake, and will cause paralysis, instead of bleeding
  • Russell’s Viper is mainly vasculotoxic, but also neurotoxic to some extent
  • Krait and Sea Snake have minimal local symptoms
  • Russell’s viper is mainly vasculotoxic, but also has some neurotoxic features
  • Most common poisonous snake in India are (Big Four): 
    • Krait (Most Common)
    • Cobra,
    • Russell’s Viper
    • Saw Scaled Viper
  • Anti snake venom (ASV) in India is effective against all the above 4 snakes (polyvalent). It does not have antiserum against pit viper, but still partially effective due to cross antibodies
  • In Neurotoxic snakes, neostigmine should also be given in addition to ASV

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cobra:

 

  • Type: Neurotoxic snake.
  • Symptoms: Causes paralysis rather than bleeding.
  • Mechanism: Cobra venom affects the nervous system, leading to paralysis.

 

Option C. Wasp Bite:

 

Local: there is pain, itching, redness and slight Swelling at the site of the sting. 

 

Systemic: Systemic reactions occur due to multiple stinging with signs of GIT disturbance (nausea, vomiting and diarrhea), sweating, bronchospasm, hypotension, shock and unconsciousness.

 

Immediate anaphylactic reactions may be seen in some cases.

 

Option D. Scorpion Bite:

 

Action: The venom is a potent autonomic stimulator, resulting in the release of massive amounts of catecholamines from the adrenals. It has also some direct effect on the myocardium.

 

Signs and Symptoms Dysfunction of cranial nerve and hyperexcitability of skeletal muscles develop within hours.

 

Local: Little swelling, but prominent radiating pain, reddening, paraesthesia, and hyperesthesia which is accentuated by tapping on the affected area (tap test).

 

Systemic: Nausea, vomiting, restlessness, fever, headache, blurred vision, abnormal eye movement, profuse sweating and salivation, lacrimation, rhinorrhoea, slurred speech, muscular fasciculations, jerking and shaking, slow pulse, cyanosis, convulsions, coma and respiratory depression, and death

 

Treatment of Scorpion bite: Anti scorpion venom, Prazosin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Viper bites are characterized by profuse bleeding, pain, redness, and blister formation due to their vasculotoxic venom.

questions.text: Which of the following would most likely lead to a decrease in the intensity of the murmur in a patient with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Squatting

 

In hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), the intensity of the murmur is influenced by the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. Various maneuvers and medications can affect this obstruction by altering preload (the volume of blood in the ventricles before contraction) or afterload (the resistance the heart must pump against).

 

Squatting increases preload by squeezing the peripheral veins and increasing venous return to the heart. This increase in preload reduces LVOT obstruction, thereby decreasing the murmur's intensity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Digoxin: Digoxin increases contractility. In HCM, increased contractility can worsen LVOT obstruction, thereby increasing the intensity of the murmur and worsening the murmur.

 

Option C. Valsalva: The Valsalva maneuver reduces preload by decreasing venous return to the heart. This reduction in preload can increase LVOT obstruction, leading to a louder murmur.

 

Option D. Furosemide: By reducing preload, furosemide increases LVOT obstruction and murmur intensity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increasing preload (e.g., through squatting) reduces LVOT obstruction in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, leading to a decrease in the murmur's intensity.

choices.text: Reassure and review the couple after 6 months

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman accompanied by her mother-in-law comes to the infertility clinic. She has been having regular intercourse for 6 months but is not able to conceive. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reassure and review the couple after 6 months

 

Infertility is defined as the inability of a couple to conceive after 1 year of unprotected intercourse. For women under the age of 35, it is recommended to wait and try for one year before starting any investigations. Since the woman in this scenario is only 23 years old and has been trying to conceive for only 6 months, the best approach is to reassure her and advise her to continue trying. Investigations are not indicated at this stage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Semen analysis for husband: Although semen analysis is an essential part of infertility workup, it is typically not indicated until the couple has been trying to conceive for at least one year if the woman is under 35 years old.

 

Option C. Hysterolaparoscopy: This is an invasive procedure used to evaluate the female reproductive tract, typically reserved for cases where initial evaluations suggest abnormalities or for women who have been trying to conceive for a longer period.

 

Option D. Diagnostic hysteroscopy: This procedure is used to examine the inside of the uterus and is generally indicated for investigating suspected uterine abnormalities or after a longer period of unsuccessful conception attempts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For women under 35 years old, it is recommended to try to conceive for one year before starting infertility investigations.

questions.text: Prophylaxis is available for all of the following, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Hepatitis C

 

Explanation:

 

No effective prophylaxis is currently available for hepatitis C. Unlike hepatitis A, B, and E, there is no vaccine or immunoglobulin preparation that can provide passive or active immunization against HCV infection. The primary preventive strategies for hepatitis C focus on screening blood products, avoiding needle sharing, and implementing universal precautions in healthcare settings. Post-exposure prophylaxis with antiviral agents has not been established as effective for preventing HCV infection after exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis A: Prophylaxis for hepatitis A is available through both active and passive immunization. Active immunization involves formalin-inactivated vaccines (Havrix and Vaqta), while passive immunization uses immune globulin (IG). Hepatitis A vaccination provides long-lasting protection, and IG can be effective when administered before exposure or early in the incubation period.

 

Option B. Hepatitis B: Both active and passive prophylaxis are available for hepatitis B. Active immunization uses recombinant vaccines containing HBsAg (Recombivax-HB and Engerix-B). Passive immunization with hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) is used for post-exposure prophylaxis. The combination of HBIG and vaccine is recommended for certain high-risk exposures.

 

Option D. Hepatitis E: Safe and effective recombinant vaccines for hepatitis E have been developed and are available in endemic areas. The Chinese hepatitis E vaccine has demonstrated long-lasting protection in clinical trials, documented for up to 4.5 years. While not widely available in the United States, prophylaxis for hepatitis E does exist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis C stands alone among the major hepatitis viruses as having no established prophylactic vaccine or immunoglobulin preparation, making prevention dependent on avoiding exposure.

questions.text: Patient can see 3 green dots on the Worth’s 4 dots test. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) RE suppression

 

The Worth 4-dot test is used to evaluate binocular vision and identify suppression of one eye or diplopia. The patient wears red-green goggles where the Red lens is over the Right eye (RE) and the green lens is over the left eye (LE). Normally, a person should see four dots: one red, two green, and one white dot that appears either as red, green, or mixed (brown), depending on which eye is dominant or if both eyes are functioning equally.

 

If a patient sees only three green dots, it indicates suppression of the right eye (RE). This is because the right eye, which should see the red dot, is not contributing to the vision, leading the patient to perceive only the green dots seen by the left eye.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crossed diplopia: In crossed diplopia, images from the right eye appear on the left side and vice versa, causing overlapping images. This does not match the scenario where only three green dots are seen.

 

 

Option B. Uncrossed diplopia: Uncrossed diplopia occurs when images appear on the same side as the eye seeing them. It would involve seeing more dots (double vision) rather than missing a dot due to suppression.

 

 

Option D. LE suppression: Left eye suppression would result in the patient seeing only two red dots, as the left eye is not contributing to the vision. This does not match the observed scenario of seeing three green dots.

 

Educational Objective:


Seeing three green dots on the Worth 4-dot test indicates right eye suppression (RE suppression), as the right eye is not seeing the red dot.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain that had been ongoing for the past 24 hours. He reported that he had been consuming alcohol heavily for the past few weeks. The physical examination revealed tenderness in the upper abdomen with no visible signs of jaundice. Pancreatitis was suspected, and a CT scan was performed, which revealed lesions with fluid collected near the body of the pancreas. The patient was started on appropriate treatment, and blood tests were ordered to help diagnose the condition. Which enzyme is most likely to be elevated in this scenario? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serum lipase

 

  • An alcoholic patient with acute pancreatitis is most likely to have elevated serum lipase levels.
  •  Clinical findings and elevated pancreatic enzymes in the plasma are used to diagnose acute pancreatitis.
  • Lipase is a more sensitive and specific marker of acute pancreatitis than amylase, which can be elevated in other conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum GGT : GGT (Gamma-glutamyltransferase) is an enzyme primarily found in the liver. It is an important marker for liver disease, especially conditions associated with bile duct obstruction. Elevated GGT would not specifically indicate pancreatitis.

 

Option B. CEA : CEA (Carcinoembryonic antigen) is a tumor marker, primarily used to monitor certain types of cancers, particularly colorectal cancer. It can be elevated in some pancreatic cancers as well, but it's not specifically used to diagnose or monitor acute pancreatitis.

 

Option D. Serum bilirubin: Bilirubin is a product of red blood cell breakdown and is processed by the liver. Elevated serum bilirubin levels can indicate liver disease or a blockage of the bile duct, which can be due to a stone, tumor, or other causes. In the context of pancreatitis, elevated bilirubin can be seen in biliary pancreatitis when a gallstone obstructs the common bile duct, but it's not a specific marker for pancreatitis itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Serum lipase is the most specific enzyme for diagnosing acute pancreatitis, especially in cases related to alcohol consumption.
  •  It rises within 12 to 24 hours of pancreatic injury and remains elevated for 7-14 days, making it a crucial diagnostic marker for this condition.

choices.text: Apical segment of Right lower lobe consolidation
Posterior segment of right lower lobe consolidation

questions.text: A patient presents in OPD with a history of fever and cough for 5 days. On auscultation, crepts were heard on right side. Chest X-ray is given below. Mark the correct finding in this case? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Right middle lobe consolidation

 

Patient presenting with a history of fever and cough for 5 days suggests diagnosis pneumonia. The chest X-ray showing opacities with obscuration of the right cardiac border is suggestive of right middle lobe consolidation.

 

Right middle lobe pathology causes the obscuration of right cardiac border. In addition, the lateral view shows the opacity overlying the heart. In case of lower lobe opacities, the opacity overlays the spine.

 

 

The left image is a normal chest radiograph with the red line indicating the silhouette of the right heart border and right middle lobe.

 

The right image shows the same red line delineating where the silhouette should be, but is lost due to consolidation in the right middle lobe.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right middle lobe consolidation is suggested by the obscuration of the right heart border and the specific location of opacity on the chest X-ray, aligned with the patient's clinical presentation of respiratory symptoms. This finding is crucial for diagnosing the specific location of pneumonia, guiding appropriate treatment.

choices.text: Acute abdominal pain and visceral symptoms

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Tabes dorsalis? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Deep tendon reflexes are brisk

 

Explanation:

 

Tabes dorsalis is a late manifestation of neurosyphilis characterized by degeneration of the posterior columns and dorsal roots of the spinal cord. A hallmark feature of tabes dorsalis is the absence or significant reduction of deep tendon reflexes (hyporeflexia or areflexia), not brisk reflexes. The loss of reflexes occurs due to the interruption of the afferent limb of the reflex arc as posterior root fibers degenerate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seen in neurosyphilis: Tabes dorsalis is a form of neurosyphilis that occurs as a late manifestation of tertiary syphilis, usually appearing 15-20 years after the initial infection. It involves the progressive degeneration of the posterior columns of the spinal cord due to untreated syphilis infection.

 

Option C. Loss of vibration sense: Tabes dorsalis classically presents with loss of proprioception and vibration sense due to damage to the posterior columns of the spinal cord, which carry these sensory modalities. This sensory ataxia contributes to the characteristic gait disturbance.

 

Option D. Acute abdominal pain and visceral symptoms: Tabetic crises, characterized by episodes of severe pain (particularly abdominal pain, "gastric crises"), are a recognized feature of tabes dorsalis. These crises can mimic acute abdominal emergencies and other visceral conditions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Tabes dorsalis, a manifestation of neurosyphilis, typically presents with absent deep tendon reflexes (not brisk reflexes), impaired proprioception and vibration sense, lancinating pain, and characteristic gait ataxia (sensory ataxia).

questions.text: A woman presents to the OPD with complaints of amenorrhoea for the past year. She has a history of postpartum hemorrhage and lactational failure. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sheehan’s syndrome

 

  • The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Sheehan's syndrome.
  • When postpartum hemorrhage causes vascular thrombosis of the pituitary vessels (pituitary apoplexy) and panhypopituitarism. It is characterized by:
    • Lactation failure - due to prolactin deficiency
    • Amenorrhea - due to anovulation caused by reduced gonadotropin activity
    • Loss of sexual and axillary hair
    • Hypothyroidism - due to decreased TSH secretion
    • Adrenal insufficiency - due to low ACTH

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rotor Syndrome: Also known as Rotor type hyperbilirubinemia, is an autosomal recessive disease and a rare cause of mixed direct (conjugated) and indirect (unconjugated) hyperbilirubinemia. The disease is characterized by non-hemolytic jaundice due to chronic elevation of predominantly conjugated bilirubin

 

Option C. Prolactinoma: This will not present lactation failure. Instead, there will be galactorrhea and symptoms like headache, luring of vision due to pressure effects of the prolactinoma.

 

Option D. Acromegaly: It is a disorder that results in excess growth of certain parts of the human body. It is caused by excess growth hormone (GH) after the growth plates have closed. The initial symptom is typically enlargement of the hands and feet. There may also be an enlargement of the forehead, jaw, and nose. Other symptoms may include joint pain, thicker skin, deepening of the voice, headaches, and problems with vision. Complications of the disease may include type 2 diabetes, sleep apnea, and high blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sheehan’s syndrome is characterized by postpartum hemorrhage leading to vascular thrombosis of the pituitary vessels, resulting in panhypopituitarism with symptoms like lactation failure and amenorrhea.

 

Ref: Page no 458, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is an opsonin? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) C3b

 

C3b functions as an opsonin.

 

Opsonization: - The process of coating a foreign particle and preparing it for phagocytosis. The substances involved in this process are called opsonins.

 

Include:

 

  • Mannose-binding lectin
  • IgM and Fc receptor of IgG
  • CRP
  • Fibrinogen
  • C3b, C4b, C5b

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. C3a and C. C5a: These are anaphylatoxins involved in inflammation and promoting chemotaxis.

 

Option D. C6: Part of the membrane attack complex (MAC) of the complement system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

C3b is an opsonin important in the immune system for marking pathogens for phagocytosis, enhancing the body's ability to clear infections.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a mobile, rubbery mass in her left breast. A histological image is provided. What is the most likely diagnosis for the given image? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fibroadenoma 

 

The finding of mobile breast and the histological image showing a mixture of stromal and epithelial tissue, often described as having a 'staghorn’ appearance is seen in fibroadenoma.

 

This is a common benign tumor of the breast, usually presenting as a mobile, rubbery mass. Histologically, it shows a mixture of stromal and epithelial tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC): This is the most common type of breast cancer. Histologically, IDC typically shows abnormal, invasive glandular cells that originate from the ducts and invade surrounding breast tissue.

 

Option C. Phyllodes tumor: This is a rare breast tumor that can be benign or malignant. Histologically, it is similar to fibroadenoma but typically shows increased stromal cellularity and leaf-like projections. It is not mobile.

 

Option D. Lobular carcinoma in-situ (LCIS): LCIS is a non-invasive condition in which abnormal cells are found in the lobules of the breast. Histologically, it shows small, uniform cells that fill and expand the lobules.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fibroadenoma is the likely diagnosis of a mobile, rubbery breast mass in a young woman, characterized histologically by a benign proliferation of stromal and epithelial components.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is least likely to be associated with Infective Endocarditis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Small ASD.

 

Isolated atrial septal defect (ASD) is specifically excluded from cardiac conditions predisposing to infective endocarditis. When evaluating endocarditis risk factors, conditions that create turbulent blood flow with high-velocity jets are most concerning, as they damage endothelial surfaces and provide locations for bacterial adherence. Small ASDs typically create minimal hemodynamic disturbance and lack the significant turbulent flow pattern that promotes vegetation formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Small VSD: Ventricular septal defects, even small ones, create abnormal blood flow patterns with higher-velocity jets that can damage endothelium, creating a nidus for bacterial adherence. While repaired VSDs have lower risk, unrepaired VSDs remain a predisposing condition for endocarditis.

 

Option C. Mild MR: Mitral regurgitation represents a valvular abnormality with regurgitant flow that predisposes to endocarditis. The turbulent flow across the abnormal valve creates conditions favorable for bacterial adherence and vegetation formation, even when the regurgitation is mild.

 

Option D. Mild TR: Tricuspid regurgitation, like mitral regurgitation, creates turbulent flow patterns that can damage endothelium and facilitate bacterial adhesion. Valvular regurgitation at any valve is a recognized risk factor for infectious endocarditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While most valvular and structural cardiac abnormalities increase endocarditis risk through turbulent flow patterns, isolated atrial septal defect stands as a notable exception, carrying minimal risk for infective endocarditis.

questions.text: During the forensic examination of dry semen from undergarment of a rape victim. What specific test is employed to ascertain the presence of sperm? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barberio test

 

When examining dry semen stains found on the undergarment of a rape victim, the Barberio test is the specific test employed to ascertain the presence of sperm. Although the Barberio test is not considered the most reliable test for semen, it can still yield positive results in dry stains, making it the most suitable choice among the given options for this particular scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. B. Acid phosphatase test: The acid phosphatase test is indeed a good test for detecting semen, but it is not the best choice for dry stains. The activity of acid phosphatase decreases rapidly with time, making it less effective in detecting the presence of sperm in older, dry semen stains.

 

Option. C. Papanicolaou smear: The Papanicolaou (Pap) smear is not a test used for detecting semen. It is a cytological test used primarily for screening cervical cancer and other abnormalities in the female reproductive system.

 

Option. D. Florence test: The Florence test is another test used for detecting semen, but it is not mentioned as the most appropriate test for dry semen stains in the given scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When examining dry semen stains, such as those found on the undergarment of a rape victim, the Barberio test is the specific test employed to ascertain the presence of sperm, as it can yield positive results even in dry stains.

choices.text: Multiple corpora lutea cysts in the ovaries

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of Stein-Leventhal syndrome, also known as Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS)? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Multiple corpora lutea cysts in the ovaries

 

The correct answer is A because PCOS is characterized by multiple follicular cysts at varying stages of maturation and atresia, not corpora lutea cysts. The pathology of PCOS shows that these are arrested follicles that fail to develop fully and ovulate. Corpus luteum formation requires ovulation, which typically doesn't occur in PCOS due to hormonal imbalances.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thick ovarian tunica albuginea: Correct characteristic of PCOS

 

  • Histologically, thickening of tunica albuginea is a characteristic finding
  • The capsule is described as thickened and pearly white in color
  • This feature contributes to the classic appearance on examination and imaging

 

Option C. Obesity: Correct characteristic of PCOS

 

  • Increasing obesity (especially abdominal – 50%) is a common clinical feature
  • Obesity is listed as one of the defining features in the original Stein-Leventhal description
  • Central obesity is recognized as an important contributory factor to insulin resistance

 

Option D. Hirsutism: Correct characteristic of PCOS

 

  • Hirsutism is present in approximately 70% of PCOS patients
  • This occurs due to increased androgens and is often accompanied by acne
  • Severity can be measured using the Ferriman-Gallwey scoring system

 

Educational Objective:

 

PCOS is characterized by arrested follicular development resulting in multiple follicular cysts (not corpus luteum cysts), with clinical manifestations including hirsutism, obesity, and menstrual irregularities due to chronic anovulation and hyperandrogenism.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used as an anti-smoking agent? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Varenicline

 

Varenicline is an FDA-approved medication that helps individuals quit smoking by reducing the craving and withdrawal symptoms associated with tobacco use. It acts as a partial agonist at alpha4 beta2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, which can both stimulate the receptor (to reduce craving) and block nicotine from binding (to reduce the rewarding effects of cigarettes).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Busulfan: An alkylating agent used primarily in the treatment of chronic myelogenous leukemia.

 

Option B. Acamprosate: Used to treat alcohol dependence by reducing the craving for alcohol.

 

Option D. Gabapentin: An anticonvulsant that is also used for neuropathic pain and certain mood disorders.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Varenicline is a partial agonist at α4β2 & α7 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. As a partial agonist it prevents high and reinforcement and also controls craving and withdrawal due to tobacco use. It is the most effective agent for tobacco use disorders.

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 505.
